title: Safety vs. Schedule Pressure
description: You are the lead engineer on a new pedestrian bridge project. During the final inspection, your team discovers a critical structural flaw in a key supporting beam that could lead to collapse under high stress (e.g., during a severe storm or a major public event). Fixing the flaw will require a two-month delay and significantly increase the project cost, incurring a $2 million penalty as per the contract. Your project manager urges you to sign off, arguing that the flaw is likely minor and the chance of failure is statistically low, pressuring you not to jeopardize the company's reputation and finances.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Immediately halt construction/opening and formally report the critical flaw to the client and your company's senior management. Recommend the necessary redesign and repair, documenting all findings.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Upholds the primary ethical duty to protect the public safety and welfare, regardless of cost or schedule.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Agree to sign off on the structure, but secretly draft a letter to your superior and the client after the fact, documenting your concerns and assigning liability to the construction team/project manager.
responses.evaluation: Poor. You knowingly allow a dangerous structure to open, violating public trust. The documentation is an inadequate, self-serving attempt to dodge responsibility.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Conduct a second, independent, and thorough analysis with a different team to verify the criticality of the flaw before making a final decision, but keep the initial findings confidential for now.
responses.evaluation: Fair. It shows a commitment to certainty (due diligence) but risks delaying the necessary safety action and potentially covers up the initial finding temporarily.

title: Whistleblowing on Environmental Non-Compliance
description: You are a chemical engineer working for a manufacturing plant. You discover that your company is routinely dumping untreated wastewater into a nearby river late at night, in violation of local and federal environmental regulations, to save money on treatment costs. You first report this to your immediate supervisor, who tells you to "mind your own business" and that "everyone does it." You know this pollution is harming the local ecosystem and potentially the downstream water supply.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Resign immediately, citing the company's unethical and illegal practices in your exit interview, but take no further action.
responses.evaluation: Poor. While you refuse to participate, you fail in the professional duty to protect the public and stop an ongoing illegal act.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Follow the company's internal reporting chain (even if it's resistant) and, if no action is taken, anonymously report the violation with documented evidence to the relevant environmental protection agency.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Follows the chain of command first, then fulfills the duty to the public interest by escalating the matter to external authorities.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Continue working but discreetly gather evidence (photos, internal memos, test results) and use it to threaten your supervisor into changing the practice and giving you a promotion/raise.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Using the discovery for personal gain constitutes extortion and an abuse of professional position.

title: Data Integrity and Client Trust
description: You are a data scientist hired by a tech startup to validate the performance claims of their new AI-powered investment software. You find that the software's claimed 90% accuracy rate is actually closer to 65% and that the published marketing results have been significantly "cherry-picked" and manipulated. The CEO informs you that the company is about to close a major funding round based on these inflated metrics and that revealing the truth would bankrupt the company.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Adjust your report to reflect the 65% accuracy rate accurately, but include a paragraph suggesting "future optimization potential" to mitigate the negative impact, hoping the CEO will still find a way to proceed.
responses.evaluation: Fair. You uphold professional truthfulness, but the added context is a weak attempt to compromise, potentially still misleading investors.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Refuse to submit a fraudulent report. State clearly that you cannot compromise the integrity of the data and offer to help the CEO explain the actual performance honestly to the investors.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Upholds the duty of truthfulness, professional integrity, and honesty in reporting data and facts.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Edit the report to show the 90% figure as requested, rationalizing that saving the company and its employees' jobs is a greater ethical good than minor data inflation.
responses.evaluation: Bad. You actively engage in fraudulent misrepresentation, harming potential investors and violating the fundamental principle of honesty.

title: Conflict of Interest and Bidding
description: You are a senior civil engineer involved in reviewing bids for a major municipal water project. Your sibling's construction company submits a bid that is technically sound and slightly lower than the next competitor. You have not disclosed your familial relationship because you believe you can remain objective. Another engineer raises a question about the relationship, and you realize you should have disclosed it earlier.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Disclose the familial relationship immediately to the selection committee and recuse yourself entirely from the review process related to that specific bid.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Properly manages the conflict of interest by removing yourself from the decision, ensuring an objective and fair bidding process.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Continue with the review and vote for your sibling's bid, arguing that it is the best one and that you have a right to your opinion and vote.
responses.evaluation: Bad. You prioritize a personal interest over the appearance of fairness, leading to a biased decision and violating conflict-of-interest policies.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Disclose the relationship but state that you will only participate in the technical evaluation of all bids, abstaining from the final scoring or voting.
responses.evaluation: Fair. While partial recusal is better than none, the appearance of a conflict remains, making full recusal the more ethically sound choice.

title: Software License Compliance
description: You are managing a team of 50 software developers. To save costs, your department head instructed you to purchase licenses for only 30 copies of an expensive, specialized engineering software, with the expectation that developers will "share" or use unlicensed copies when necessary. Audits are rare, but if caught, the company could face massive fines and legal action.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Secretly purchase the remaining 20 licenses out of your project's contingency budget without informing your department head, effectively correcting the compliance issue.
responses.evaluation: Fair. You solve the ethical and legal problem but go against your superior's direction and misuse contingency funds.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Document your concern in an email to your department head and the company's legal counsel, stating that you cannot manage the team under conditions that require illegal use of software, demanding the full purchase.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Upholds legal compliance and professional responsibility, refusing to participate in illegal activity and creating an official record.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Carry on with the 30 licenses, advising your team members to be careful and only install the software on their computers right before they need to use it.
responses.evaluation: Bad. You knowingly perpetuate illegal activity (software piracy/licensing violation) and encourage your team to engage in deceit.

title: Project Transparency and Failure
description: You are a mechanical engineer whose newly designed industrial robot arm has failed spectacularly during client testing, causing significant property damage but no injuries. An internal review suggests the failure was due to an unforeseen fatigue issue in a non-critical component. Your CEO proposes telling the client that the failure was due to "operator error and unforeseen external circumstances" to protect the company's insurance premiums and reputation.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Agree with the CEO's proposal and draft a report that places the blame on the client's operating procedures.
responses.evaluation: Bad. You actively lie to a client, evade professional responsibility, and hide a design flaw that could cause future harm.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Insist on a full, factual, and transparent report to the client detailing the technical cause (the fatigue issue) and propose a clear plan for redesign, compensation, and repair.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Upholds truthfulness, transparency, and professional accountability.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Write a vague report that mentions the fatigue issue but heavily emphasizes how the client's operational environment contributed to the failure, splitting the blame equally.
responses.evaluation: Poor. You dilute the truth to shift blame, which is deceptive and fails to take full responsibility for a product failure.

title: Exploiting Developing World Labor Laws
description: You are designing a high-tech electronic device. Your manufacturing partner suggests moving the assembly line to a country with significantly laxer labor laws and minimal environmental regulations, which would save your company 40% in production costs. This move would involve hiring employees at below-standard wages and generating much more local pollution than is legal in your home country.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Proceed with the move, arguing that your primary responsibility is to the company's shareholders (fiduciary duty) and that local labor laws are the responsibility of the host country's government, not yours.
responses.evaluation: Poor. While legally permissible in that country, it ignores the professional ethical duty to consider the societal and environmental impacts of engineering work globally.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Insist on a clause in the manufacturing contract that mandates the assembly plant adhere to your home country's labor and environmental standards (or equivalent high standards), even if it reduces the cost savings.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Integrates global social responsibility and environmental stewardship into the engineering process.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Recommend a different country that offers cost savings but has moderately better (but still not great) labor and environmental standards than the proposed option.
responses.evaluation: Fair. It's a compromise that shows awareness but doesn't fully address the ethical concerns of seeking the lowest possible standard.

title: Misleading Advertising and Product Capabilities
description: You are a machine learning engineer. The marketing department is about to launch a major campaign for your new product, a 'smart home hub'. The advertising claims the hub can "diagnose medical conditions with 95% accuracy" using voice analysis. You know this capability is not true; the feature is only a basic mood-analysis tool and has never been tested in a medical context.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Contact the marketing department and your manager to demand the immediate retraction of the misleading claim, citing the potential for public harm and professional misconduct.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Fulfills the duty to prevent misrepresentation and safeguard the public from potentially harmful medical misinformation.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Keep quiet, noting that it's the marketing department's responsibility, and your job is merely to write code, not vet ad copy.
responses.evaluation: Bad. You knowingly allow a harmful, misleading statement about your product to go public, violating the duty of truthfulness.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Draft a quick disclaimer to be included in the product manual, stating the feature is "not a medical device," but allow the marketing copy to remain.
responses.evaluation: Poor. The disclaimer is inadequate to counter the high-impact, misleading advertising claim.

title: Handling a Subordinate's Error
description: A junior engineer on your team makes a significant calculation error that, if undetected, would have resulted in an expensive but non-life-threatening failure in a newly manufactured product. You catch the error during your final review, fix it easily, and the product is shipped successfully. The junior engineer is unaware of the mistake, and you feel they should be held accountable but don't want to ruin their career.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Fix the error silently, then write up the engineer for a formal performance review, documenting the error but not explaining to them what they did wrong.
responses.evaluation: Poor. You fulfill the immediate technical duty but fail in your ethical duty to mentor and educate your subordinate, preventing them from learning a critical lesson.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Sit down privately with the junior engineer, show them the error, explain the gravity of the potential failure, and use it as a teaching opportunity to reinforce proper checking procedures.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Upholds the duty to maintain technical competence in your team and to mentor junior colleagues professionally and ethically.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Fix the error, then make a general announcement to the whole team about the importance of double-checking work, hoping the junior engineer gets the hint.
responses.evaluation: Fair. You address the issue (checking) but fail to provide the specific, private, and actionable feedback the junior engineer needs to improve.

title: Prioritizing Accessibility
description: You are designing a public-facing web application for a government service. The client has explicitly requested that you skip implementing accessibility features (like screen reader compatibility, keyboard navigation, and high contrast modes) because they consider it a non-essential feature and want to launch two months sooner, saving the project $50,000. Implementing these features is a standard best practice but not strictly required by the contract.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Skip the features, noting that you are only obligated to fulfill the contract terms as written and the client made the final decision.
responses.evaluation: Bad. You fail in the duty to ensure that your work benefits and is accessible to all segments of the population, especially those with disabilities.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Strongly advise the client in writing that skipping accessibility features creates a significant barrier for users with disabilities and recommend delaying the launch to include them, offering a cost-saving solution for implementation.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Upholds the ethical duty to consider the broader societal impact and advocate for universal access and inclusion in engineering design.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Implement a few basic, low-cost accessibility features without telling the client, leaving out the more time-consuming or expensive ones.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Better than nothing, but it's a deceptive partial fix that doesn't fully solve the issue of broad accessibility for all users.

title: Intellectual Property Leak by Accident
description: You are a hardware engineer presenting at an international conference. During your talk, you accidentally reveal a slide containing proprietary chip design details that have not been patented yet. After the presentation, your colleague tells you that if competitors act quickly, they could legally use aspects of your design. Your company hasn't noticed the mistake‚Äîyet.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Immediately notify your company's legal and engineering leadership, provide the slide deck, and document the disclosure so appropriate IP protection steps can be taken.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. You take responsibility, allow the company to manage risk, and maintain professional honesty.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Quietly remove the slide from future decks and hope no one else noticed, avoiding any mention to management.
responses.evaluation: Poor. You conceal a significant IP risk and deprive your employer of informed decision-making.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Suggest to management that they rush a patent filing but downplay your role in the leak.
responses.evaluation: Fair. You act to mitigate harm but fail to accept accountability.

title: Bribery Attempt During Safety Inspection
description: As a structural inspector, you evaluate a new high-rise. The contractor privately offers you a $20,000 "bonus" to overlook several minor code violations that won't immediately affect safety but may reduce long-term resilience. You know refusing may strain the business relationship.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Reject the bribe, document the attempt, and report both the violations and the bribery to the regulatory authority.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Preserves professional integrity and protects public safety.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Reject the bribe and document violations but choose not to report the bribery to avoid legal complications.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Proper inspection conduct, but failure to report bribery encourages future misconduct.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Accept the bribe on the condition that the contractor corrects at least some of the violations.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Engaging in bribery is a serious ethical breach.

title: AI Model Bias Discovery
description: You find that your company's facial recognition system misidentifies certain demographic groups at a significantly higher rate. Re-training will delay deployment by six months and cost substantial resources. Management wants to ship now and "improve it later."

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Demand the system be withheld from deployment until the bias is addressed; provide data and formal recommendations.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Prioritizes fairness, safety, and non-discrimination.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Recommend a future patch but allow deployment now, since the product still performs "well enough" overall.
responses.evaluation: Poor. Accepting discriminatory outcomes violates ethical duties.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Informally consult diverse experts to propose partial mitigation strategies while continuing development.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Shows initiative but doesn't prevent harmful deployment.

title: Dangerous Shortcut in QA Testing
description: Your QA team is behind schedule, and your manager recommends skipping vibration testing for a drone battery module, calling it "low risk." But vibration failure modes are known to cause fires in similar products.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Refuse to skip the test and escalate the issue to engineering leadership, providing risk assessments.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Prevents potentially catastrophic harm.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Perform abbreviated testing that isn't fully compliant but at least covers the basics.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Better than skipping entirely but still not adequate.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Follow the manager's directive without objection.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Neglects critical safety responsibilities.

title: Conflicting Interests in Peer Review
description: You are peer-reviewing a journal submission by a competing research lab. Their work is impressive and could overshadow yours. Your collaborator suggests slowing the review or adding nitpicky criticisms to delay publication.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Conduct a timely, fair, and unbiased review, recommending publication if warranted.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Maintains academic integrity.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Delay the review by a few weeks "due to workload," subtly giving your lab more time to publish.
responses.evaluation: Poor. Manipulative and harms scientific progress.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Offer generally constructive comments but exaggerate minor issues to lengthen revision cycles.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Intentionally obstructs competitors.

title: Safety Issue in Autonomous Vehicle Code
description: While reviewing logs, you discover a rare but reproducible software bug that causes an autonomous car to misinterpret a traffic light during certain lighting conditions. Fixing it will delay launch by three months.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Halt release, document the bug, and require correction before public deployment.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Prevents potentially life-threatening risks.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Publish the model but advise users in documentation that "rare false signals may occur."
responses.evaluation: Bad. Critical safety information must not be buried in fine print.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Implement a temporary software patch that reduces (but does not eliminate) the error rate.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Attempts mitigation but doesn't fully address a known safety hazard.

title: Misuse of Company Resources for Personal Project
description: You want to prototype a personal invention using your company's advanced lab equipment. It won't interfere with work hours, but company policy forbids personal use without explicit approval. You worry leadership will deny the request.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Ask management formally for permission and present a clear plan; accept the decision.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Transparent and respectful of company property.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Use the equipment after hours, rationalizing that no one will notice and there's no harm.
responses.evaluation: Poor. Violates trust and misuses company assets.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Ask a sympathetic lab technician to quietly allow access without notifying leadership.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Involves others in policy violations.

title: Redacting Sensitive Customer Data
description: During a system migration, you find thousands of customer support logs containing unredacted personal information‚Äîaddresses, SSNs, medical conditions. Cleaning the data properly will require delaying the migration by several weeks.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Halt migration until the data is properly anonymized and compliance teams are notified.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Protects users' privacy and meets legal responsibility.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Perform minimal masking on the riskiest fields and proceed with the migration.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Reduces harm somewhat, but incomplete and risky.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Ignore the issue since the logs were already stored insecurely to begin with.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Continues privacy violations.

title: Misallocation of Research Grant Funds
description: Your lab won a grant to develop medical imaging software. Your PI suggests allocating part of the grant to upgrade lab furniture and "miscellaneous comfort items" unrelated to the proposal.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Inform the PI that grant funds must be used as promised and report the misuse risk to the university's research compliance office if necessary.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Protects scientific integrity and legal compliance.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Allow some minor deviations since the improvements indirectly benefit research productivity.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Pragmatic but still ethically questionable.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Fully support the PI's plan because "everyone misallocates funds a little."
responses.evaluation: Bad. Encourages financial misconduct.

title: Hazardous Building Material Discovery
description: You're inspecting an older building and find asbestos in a mechanical room. The client wants to proceed with renovations immediately and asks you to "look the other way" while construction begins, claiming removal costs are too high.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Stop the renovation and formally report the hazardous material, requiring proper abatement before any work proceeds.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Protects workers' health and legal compliance.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Allow work to proceed but request workers be given masks and told to avoid disturbing the insulation.
responses.evaluation: Poor. Grossly insufficient protection.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Suggest delaying only the areas near the asbestos while allowing other renovations to start.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Limited mitigation but still risky.

title: Unequal Salary Discovery as a Manager
description: You discover that two engineers with similar roles and performance have vastly different salaries due to inherited pay structures. HR hasn't addressed the disparity, and the higher-paid engineer is your long-time colleague.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Advocate to HR for correcting the disparity, provide documentation, and refuse to approve future evaluations until the inequity is addressed.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Promotes fairness, transparency, and justice.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Do nothing, rationalizing that pay decisions are HR's responsibility.
responses.evaluation: Poor. Avoids your duty to advocate for fair treatment.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Tell the underpaid engineer to negotiate harder next cycle, without involving HR.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Attempts support but doesn't solve systemic inequity.

title: Misrepresentation of Test Coverage
description: You lead software testing. Your manager asks you to report full coverage even though only 70% of critical functions were tested. "Nobody ever checks," he says.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Report accurate coverage figures and insist on more testing.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Truthful and protects product safety.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Report 70% but add vague language implying broader coverage.
responses.evaluation: Poor. Still misleading.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Report 100% as requested.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Falsifying data is serious misconduct.

title: Overworked Team and Excessive Hours
description: Your engineering team has been working 70-hour weeks for months. Management wants you to impose mandatory weekend work until the next milestone.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Push back and provide data on burnout, turnover, and quality decline; propose alternate scheduling or scope cuts.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Protects team welfare.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Communicate the mandate but allow informal flex time later.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Helps the team but doesn't challenge the root problem.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Fully enforce the mandate and pressure dissenters.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Harms worker wellbeing and reduces long-term project quality.

title: Unsafe Temporary Fix in Manufacturing
description: A machine in your factory is failing intermittently. A colleague suggests bypassing a safety interlock so the line can keep running at full speed.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Refuse the workaround and shut down the line until the issue is resolved safely.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Prevents harm and respects safety standards.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Bypass the interlock but add a warning sign near the machine.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Warning signs cannot replace safety systems.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Run the line at half speed while investigating the issue, avoiding the interlock bypass.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Reduces risk somewhat but still delays necessary repairs.

title: Favoritism in Promotion Decisions
description: You're evaluating candidates for a promotion. One candidate is objectively stronger, but management pressures you to select another candidate who is personally close to them.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Recommend the stronger candidate and document your reasoning.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Upholds fairness and meritocracy.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Select the weaker candidate to maintain your relationship with management.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Violates fairness.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Propose delaying the promotion and conducting more evaluations.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Avoids immediate unfairness but may delay deserved recognition.

title: Using Student Interns as Cheap Labor
description: Your company hires engineering interns and asks you to assign them work equivalent to full-time engineers, without pay increases or proper supervision.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Push for proper role definitions, training, and fair compensation.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Protects students from exploitation.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Give them full workloads but try to mentor them informally.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Helpful, but still allows exploitation.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Treat them as full-time staff because "that's how the industry works."
responses.evaluation: Bad. Enables unethical labor practices.

title: Manipulated Simulation Results
description: Your CFD simulations show that your new ventilation design fails under extreme conditions. Management asks you to "adjust the boundary conditions" to produce a passing result.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Refuse to alter results and present the accurate findings.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Upholds scientific integrity.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Adjust boundary conditions slightly to improve results but still note limitations in the appendix.
responses.evaluation: Poor. Still misleading.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Comply with management's request.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Produces fraudulent engineering results.

title: Safety Training Budget Cut
description: Your department wants to eliminate all annual safety refreshers to save time and money, even though your facility contains hazardous chemicals.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Advocate to maintain training and present data showing increased risks without it.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Protects staff welfare.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Support a reduced training schedule rather than eliminating it entirely.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Better than nothing but still insufficient.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Agree to the cuts because you trust employees already know the basics.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Neglects vital safety obligations.

title: Pressure to Approve an Incomplete Design
description: A supplier is late delivering a critical component design, and your manager wants you to sign off on preliminary documents so manufacturing can begin.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Refuse to approve until full documentation and testing are complete.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Prevents defective builds.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Approve with conditions, noting risks in your report.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Attempts mitigation but still premature.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Approve immediately to avoid delays.
responses.evaluation: Bad. Jeopardizes product reliability.

title: Personal Relationship with a Supplier Representative
description: You begin dating a representative from a company that frequently bids on your projects. Nobody knows yet.

responses.label: Response A
responses.text: Disclose the relationship and recuse yourself from all related procurement decisions.
responses.evaluation: Excellent. Avoids conflict of interest.

responses.label: Response B
responses.text: Continue participating but promise yourself you'll "stay objective."
responses.evaluation: Bad. Objectivity cannot be assumed; risk of bias is too high.

responses.label: Response C
responses.text: Stop dating the representative but do not disclose the brief relationship.
responses.evaluation: Fair. Reduces conflict risk, but lack of disclosure may still be problematic.
